awd_titl_txt: RoL:FELS:EAGER: Linking physiology, morphology, and genomics to investigate adaption to rapid environmental change
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the link between genetics, traits, and the environment will help predict how organisms respond to long-term changes in their environment. Many organisms are adapted to their local environments and advances in DNA sequencing have allowed the discovery of genes responsible for these adaptations. The migratory songbird, Willow Flycatcher, is broadly distributed across the US during the summer breeding season and therefore different populations occupy very different climates. An important example is the endangered Southwestern Willow Flycatcher, which occupies regions of the southwest US that experience intense heatwaves. This project will examine the question: How do Willow Flycatchers inhabiting different regions adapt to different climates? By measuring differences in heat tolerance and body shape and coupling these measurements with DNA sequencing, the project will provide important information about how these birds are adapted to their current environments as well as how they might respond in the future.  The project will broadly impact society via public outreach and the training of young scientists.

Standing genetic variation associated with climate has now been observed in a wide range of taxa, suggesting that adaptation could mitigate some negative effects of climate. The major knowledge gaps in understanding the evolutionary response to climate are: which traits are under selection and how will standing genetic variation change over time? In Willow Flycatchers the discovery of standing genetic variation associated with summer maximum temperatures could suggest adaptive potentials, but accurate prediction is limited by a lack of understanding of the selective mechanisms. This project will examine the genetic basis of morphological and physiological traits with known roles in thermal tolerance. Once putatively adaptive genetic variants have been identified based on their associations with relevant traits, the project will examine the distribution of these genetic variants in both contemporary and historic samples. This will build an understanding of how selection shapes adaptive genetic variation across contemporary environmental gradients, as well as explicitly test the common space-for-time substitution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As climate change proceeds, species and populations will experience conditions that are completely novel. It has become clear that in many cases evolutionary responses will be required for species persistence over the next century. Variation for climate associated traits, a prerequisite for natural selection, is already known to exist in many systems. However, gaps remain in our knowledge of how this variation arises, how it is maintained, and whether it is sufficient for population persistence. In highly mobile species like migratory birds these questions become even more complicated. Are individuals still adapted to local climate when they can travel long distances? When individuals migrate seasonally, how can they be adapted to climates in both places? When species’ overall ranges shift, will populations adapt to abiotic and biotic environments in their new range? Our project fills some of these gaps using a series of genomic analyses.


When species’ geographic ranges shift, individuals are exposed to novel conditions. An extreme example is in Anna’s hummingbird, where the northern limit has expanded from Northern California in the early 20th century to Alaska in recent years. We used genome sequencing of individuals from across the range to examine evolution associated with this expansion. We found little evidence of loss of genetic diversity or natural selection associated with the range expansion. This finding supports previous evidence that the range expansion was associated with supplemental feeding and the climate of the newly expanded range was within the previous tolerance range of the species. This work highlights that not all range shifts require evolutionary responses.


In birds that undergo seasonal migration, individuals are potentially exposed to drastically different environments on their breeding and wintering grounds. Our previous work uncovered genetic variation associated with breeding climate in multiple species of migratory birds, suggesting that birds adapt to their local conditions during the breeding season. In a single population of the endangered Southwest Willow Flycatcher, we found that genetic variation has shifted, suggesting adaptation to contemporary climate change on the breeding grounds. To connect this work to selection on the wintering grounds, we use high-resolution genetic markers to track migratory connections at the individual and population levels. In Yellow Warbler we showed that individuals tracked their precipitation niche between breeding and wintering grounds. In Willow Flycatcher, we found that some populations tracked their climate niches while others did not, showing variation within species in both total niche breadth and climate tracking. This work sets the stage for furthering our understanding of climate tracking and adaptation within species.
